lg.l: I wandered abroad on a sunshiny day,
Over the upland and over the lea,
Watching the flash of the insects at play,
And the iridescent gleams on the sea.
Perfume-laded zephyrs were wafted to me,
From out of the depths of the evergreen bowers,
Sweet with aromatic odours from tree,
Sweet, too, with languorous scent from the flowers.
I wended my way to a forest-clad dell,
Passing from sunlight to ambering shade;
Coming at last to a crystalline well,
Sparkling and cool, in the depths of the glade.
The feathery frondage of fern trees Fern trees. Most likely a reference to the ponga, or silver fern, which grows to a height of ten metres and is especially common in the North Island. made
A rich green canopy over my head,
And delicate fernlets Fernlets. Ferns typically comprise the undergrowth in New Zealand forests. of many a shade
Of emerald tintings around me were spread.
Above me a mighty puriri Puriri. Pūriri is a forest tree, growing to around 20 metres, with pale bark. spread,
With fawn-coloured limbs, shewing [sic] pale ‘gainst the gloom
Of its massive, green, and umbrageous head,
That sunbeams might pierce but never illume.
Faint waves of blushings flashed down from the bloom
Of the rata, Rata. The northern rātā is a forest tree, growing to over 40 metres, with red flowers. glowing in crimson light
As the breeze waved aside the mamaku Mamaku. Mamaku, or black tree fern. plume
Giving a glimpse of its rubescence bright.
The manukau, Manukau. Mānuka, or tea tree, is a low-growing tree with a profusion of small white flowers. crowned with its snowy bloom,
Hung over the glen, like masses of snow,
Scenting with faint, terebinthine Terebinthine. Turpentine-like. perfume,
The soft breeze that passed me with whisperings low;
The moss-covered ground was besprinkled below
With the starry drops of the petalline shower
That fluttered down like feathery snow,
From that snowy mass of manukau flower.
I laid me down under the greenwood shade;
My soul drinking in all the beauty there.
A whispering murmuring stirred in the glade,
Filling with quivering echoes the air.
I drowsily gazed at the greenery fair
Till my waking thoughts into Dreamland passed;
And I slept, but still in my sleep saw there
The mirror in which the scene was glassed.
And still, in my sleep, spread the fairy glen
In all its beauty, and all its glow;
But a softer, tenderer beauty then
Seemed over all things to softly flow;
And as I gazed in sweet accents low
A song arose from the crystalline well,
Now seeming above and now seeming below,
And these were the words of its musical swell:
"Come to the woodlands, away, away,
Come where the sunbeams with shadowings play
Shining like diamond points on the leaves
Of the bowers the drooping clematis Clematis. Likely a reference to puawananga, or white clematis, an evergreen vine that produces white flowers. weaves;
Or where the plumy fern fronds grow
Filling the air with an amberine glow;
And leaving kisses on leaf and flower
That sparkle like raindrops after a shower.
Come to the woodlands, come roam with me,
Drinking in beauty from flower and from tree;
Come, roam in the home of the Dryad at will,
Or rest on the moss-covered bank of the rill,
And there I will whisper into your ear
The dryadine secrets that we hold dear;
And my kisses shall fill your soul with love
For all things around and all things above."
And then I awoke, and that echoing song
In the forest aisles died slowly away;
While the rustling leaves seemed still to prolong
The notes, in soft cadence, from spray to spray;
And I lingered there, till the summer day
Flashed crimson banners all over the west
To tell the world it was passing away
To the great Nevermore of eternal rest.
